ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about factors, data visualization, and data cleaning. Many other topics were covered in the course related to general data analysis!
Data analysis skills
In-depth base R skills to tackle a plethora of data science/analysis problems using linear modelling, penalized linear modelling, PCA, etc. As well as rigorously checking assumptions.
data analysis
linear regression, regular expressions, ggplot, mixed effects models, variable selection, model selection, logistic regression, PCA
General topics in data analysis: Ordinary linear regression, factors, statistics behind linear regression, logistic regression, PCA, data cleanup, ggplot, mixed effects models, etc.
Basic data analysis skills, from linear regression (OLS), ridge/lasso, factors, mixed effect models, data cleaning and regex
data processing and analysis knowledge

This course was incredibly helpful because it went into more detail and forced me to be accountable for a lot of learning that had tangentially come up in other S&DS courses but was never formally taught. There were so many moments where I was like "Ohhh, so that's what they were talking about in that other S&DS class" or "Wow, I wish they had gone more in depth in that other class that mentioned this topic."
I developed a deeper understanding of data analysis techniques, with an emphasis on practice.

This was a really helpful review and extension of R skills and statistical concepts from other S&DS courses. I learned more about linear regression, logistic regression, and the use of factors, for example.
I got a general introduction to application of statistic topics in a data analysis setting.
How to look at a data set more qualitatively and think about analysis in a intuitive way.
I learned how to use R to do programming, and I learned how to deal with data.
An understanding of several data analysis tools, techniques, and methods.
I learned a lot about the practicality of data analysis. I didn't realize how misleading various procedures could be.
Data analysis skills
regression

I learned about ordinary least squares as a way to estimate linear models, variable and model selection, model diagnostics, regular expressions and data cleaning, regularization, data visualization, principal components analysis, and logistic regression.

I learned various techniques for analyzing data, including multivariate linear regression, data visualization, PCA, logistic regression, and factor analysis. I became proficient in standard R programming as well as how to decide between the various methods.
Good data analysis, data visualization and data cleaning skills
I learned about data science process and different tests

The best way to describe this class is like a thorough and contextual review of many things you probably already know from other courses. Nothing was particularly exciting or stimulating but I am more comfortable working with data than I was before the class.
Data analysis
Linear Models
R

I learned the basic geometrical concepts behind least-squares linear regression, how to calculate simple linear regression coefficients using matrix algebra, how to use contrast variables for linear regression with categorical variables, how to use ggplot and create useful graphs, how to use regular expressions, and how to penalize regression coefficients. I also became comfortable and familiar with all the terms that a regression table may have, and how we got them.
Honestly, very little. For an upper-level statistics course, I had seen most of the material in other courses 230, 312, 365, etc.
Formally learned all the forms of data analysis that were rushed and poorly covered in other classes
Various skills for data analysis. Really helpful course

Advanced data analysis programming using R, along with some theory behind various data analysis/regression techniques such as single/multiple linear regression, PCA, Lasso, and Ridge regressions. Model transformations to better fit the data, such as log transformations, stepwise regression, AIC/BIC, and interaction plots.
I learned very little. The only new material I learned was about mixed effect models. Even then, it was a very surface-level discussion about what they are and how they're used.
We learned about linear regression, hypothesis testing, LASSO regression, regularization, and various models (ex. mixed effects).
linear models, ggplots, data analytics tools, mixed effects model.
data analysis, R, linear regression in R
Review of many topics formerly covered in 312, 242, and 365. The introduction to ggplot was very useful.
skills in data analysis e.g. data cleaning, lasso and ridge regression, logistic regression, pca, mixed effects models, regex
Good
This course helped me summarize and apply all my R skills.
This course taught me so many skills pertaining to performing data analysis in R.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths - I think this course is clearly very applicable (not super theoretical) and teaches you how to work with real world data. Weaknesses - prep for midterms and finals was lacking and a rubric for the final project

Strength: strong induction instruction

weakness: whole map of the course could be earlier decided when the semester was just about to begin
The strengths were the instructors, the professor and head TF Megan were extraordinary.
great
more theory can be better

Strengths - all topics covered were reasonable and within the scope of data analysis. 
Weaknesses - not really any in particular.

Essential material as a stats major. 

Topics were quite easy, especially after taking other more rigorous stats classes. There's actually not that much material in the course, so it makes me think it's more for those entering the major rather than those who have been in the major for a while.
great content, light workload, could be harder

Strengths: this course is very well organized (very easy for students to follow along at their own pace, go through the code at their own pace, etc.). The psets were great applications of what we learned in class. Open note midterm and final policy are very real-world and much appreciated.

Weaknesses: none!
Well organized and insightful. Time to work on code alongside the instructor in class definitely kept me most engaged.

I think that the assignments for the course are good - they don't take too much time but are still helpful for understanding the material. I also appreciate Elena's emphasis on understanding edge cases for common metrics like the R^2 coefficient for linear regression.

Strengths: Elena is very nice, grading is fair. 
Weaknesses: engagement with course topics feels surface level, so it sorta felt like we spent a lot of time on a very small amount of material, but then we werent really equipped to handle any serious problems.
Material was interesting and highly applicable, but I wish the course had more energy (maybe requiring in-person lectures if the lectures have, as they did, a workshop component)?
The course is based on R programming, so my R programming skills have been improved.
The course was very well structured
Fair + well-structured assignments and assessments
Practical knowledge, could be more intense
very good

Strengths: Elena has a great vision of the class and knows exactly what she wants to teach. I appreciated the opportunity to practice the techniques we learned, both in class and on the psets. 

Weaknesses: The exams were weird, since some of the problems focused on tricky algebra instead of more relevant material.

This course is extremely practical, making it useful for any prospective data scientists. There is an abundance of in-class examples and homework assignments for students to gain hands-on experience with implementing each technique on a new dataset. The purpose of each technique is also explained clearly. However, the questions on the quizzes seem disconnected from the lecture content.
Great assignments to practice the material, exams were also quite challenging. Good practice with the in-class exercises
Computations involving the usage of package.
Strengths are the topic material. Elena is good at lecturing.
Main strength: this is a practical not theoretical course. Main weakness: the course is not very engaging with little incentive to attend lecture or do the practice activities.
This course is already well-organized and no need to be improved any more.
This course was linear models, but a dumbed down version, I dont think it is necessary for students who have taken linear models already.
It would be helpful if we had some additional notes grouped by topics not lectures

Strengths: Elena's geometric explanations of concepts was very helpful in understanding content. Also, while the problem sets were difficult at times, they did a good job of illustrating concepts and how they work. Our exams were timed and take-home, which helped alleviate a lot of finals-week stress.

Weaknesses: The problem sets weren't very representative of the midterm and test, which had questions that seemed a little out of left field, and seemed much more conceptual than we had discussed.
It was not too much work. It was not super interesting because I had seen most of the material. The assignments felt not super worthwhile.

I felt like we could have learned more and I was excited to talk about time series but we never did :/

Otherwise I was super happy with the fact that I finally learned all the little things that you sort of pick up on in other classes but never truly understand.
The strengths are that the course covers lots of aspects of data analysis.

Strengths: Extremely manageable workload, course content is very interesting, Elena is really nice

Weaknesses: I found the grading (on exams especially) to be overly picky and favoring of run-on answers

Strengths: relatively well organized. The provided class slides and code were useful.

Weakness: doesn't really cover any new material in depth. It was more like a review of concepts that we have already learned before.

Strengths: the course was not super stressful and we covered a few useful topics in data analysis. It was also nice to have the opportunity to do a final project on any dataset of my choice! It was also relatively engaging/interesting. Weaknesses: the flow of information was sometimes unclear (how one topic led to another)/I would have liked to have spent a little more time on topics that showed up heavily on the midterm (such as design matrices and factors).

Elena is definitely a great teacher! The way she explained the material was very accessible. The only thing I would say is that sometimes it felt like too much time was spent on going over the same easier material, while more complex content was glanced over. I do think that the practice exercised in class were very helpful and helped to understand the material better!
useful class to gain experience but could sometimes be unnecessarily slow and pedantic

This course feels like a big review course with nothing substantial unique to it. I did not feel like I learned that much or was intellectually stimulated, which was ironic provided that this is a 300-level class that Sekhar (our DUS) insisted I take. One can take S&DS 220 and learn everything covered in this "advanced" course.

strengths: pretty good subject material overall, pretty fair psets and exams, professor is very kind and tries her best to make things clear. weaknesses: bit easy to become disengaged with the course... though I consider this mostly my own fault
Good
This was a great course!
Course content is organized well for the student to learn.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would take this class if you're looking for a slightly higher level version of S&DS 230.
The workload is a little heavy especially if you lack programming skills
I would recommend this course to any student who wants to really bolster their programming ability to tackle real world data analysis problems.
yes

Yes, if you're looking for an introduction to data analysis techniques! Elena does a great job of helping students gain a conceptual understanding of the topics. That being said, a lot of the topics are taught in other S&DS classes as well and are not particularly challenging.

Yes, if the student is looking for an upper-level stats class to fulfill requirements. Otherwise, if you are interested in the certificate or learning about data analysis techniques, I would still recommend this class as you probably will learn new material!

If you have taken many S&DS electives, there may be significant overlap in the covered content.

I think this is a good course for those looking to brush up on data analysis skills, and it helped me reinforce some topics I wasn't super confident in. I'd say this class helped me get my post-grad job; a lot of these skills are essential for the industry jobs! If you're already coming from a more advanced stats background, this class may be too easy, and you'll end up worrying over some trivialities to do well in this class.

Also, Elena is really pretty imo, so if you need some extra motivation to go to class...
yes, fundamental for data analysis

Absolutely! This course would be great for someone in their second or third year of the S&DS major, especially the second year because it covers some very foundational topics that other S&DS courses use but don't teach. Elena is an AMAZING professor, and it was incredible to have a female S&DS professor for the first time! I am a female S&DS major, and it meant a lot to me.
Yes! Fairly easy class for the Stats major or certificate.
Yes! I think this is a helpful and pretty chill S&DS course.

Honestly maybe not. If youre looking to get a general sense for the data analysis topics you should be looking into and get some practice with basic applications, then take it. But if you want to study the intricacies of those topics, I feel like it would be more useful to just research them on your own. I was not really engaged by this class.
Yes. Elena is very nice and the class is well organized. Nothing too intense or challenging either which is nice.
Yes. If you want to be a data scientist and deal with a large amount of data, this course is just for you.
Absolutely! The content is very useful and helpful in a broad variety of statistical settings, and quite interesting to learn as well.

Yes, though if you took S&DS 230 you might find some parts of this course to be a bit repetitive (more in depth though, so if you didn't pay attention in 230 you'll probably learn a bit even from the repeated topics)
Yes
yes
Yes! You learn real skills and get a feel for what data analysis involves. Its also super low workload! A great class to develop R skills and get a feel for what to do when you see a new data set.

I would recommend this to another S&DS student who has not taking a practical course in order for them to feel comfortable using R, which is a very popular language for most statistical research. The practical nature of the course lends itself well to students who have a strong theoretical background, such as by taking S&DS 241 and 242, by expanding their programming and analytical skills.
Yes, it's good practice with R.
Yes
Yes, good upper level s and ds class. Material overlaps a lot with Linear Models (312)
Yes I would. It's not incredibly engaging, but you leave the course more comfortable working with data and learn some practical insights in the field of data science.
Yes as this course is really practical and useful!
No, again, there are other courses (eg. linear models) that teach the exact same material in a better way.
No, if you have the prerequisites then this course is not worth your time.
Yes especially for those just starting in the stats world
Yes definitely

Yeah, definitely. This is a must-take for S&DS majors - a practical class that has the perfect blend of theory and applications. The workload is very reasonable too (6 shorter psets, one every two weeks roughly, plus open laptop exams: a midterm exam and a final exam/project) and there is plenty of help in office hours and on Ed Discussion (the best question-answering course staff I have had at Yale). Elena is an awesome instructor, so I'd highly recommend taking it with her if she's offering 361 again. If you have taken 242 and 230, you definitely have the background to get a whole lot out of the class. You get out what you put in, since there are always ways to go above and beyond on assignments, but what's required is fairly minimal compared to other related classes. In all, 361 is a really good class for learning tools that will be useful however you use statistics in the future.

If you are looking for an easy class where you won't learn much, then yeah. It's very chill. But sometimes, the work can just become annoying to do because it just seems like busywork. 

The exams and quizzes are extremely frustrating because they are basically trivia questions. Elena even acknowledges this to be true because on the final, she states that these questions "are not trivia" at the top of the exam. As a result, the midterm and quizzes do not accurately reflect how well a student understands the course material.
yes
Yes yes!! Please, take this class with Elena. You definitely need some background in statistics and linear algebra, but it is great for SDS majors!
i didnt really learn much in this class but it was an easy low workload credit
If you are looking to tick a major requirement box without learning much content (or in pursuit of a class with low workload), then sure.
Really great foundation of Data Analysis course with the opportunity to go more in depth. Organized and taught really well.

Yeah, I think it's a solid elective to learn some data analysis skills. We need all the applied electives we can get in the stats department. Honestly would love some more data analysis courses in python, but this'll do the trick for R.
Good
Yes! Its a very thorough survey of data analysis.
Yes, it's a fun course and helps you improve your data analysis skills, which I find important.
